attributes.title: Explanation for reweeters network
attributes.visState:
{"title":"Explanation for reweeters network","type":"markdown","aggs":[],"params":{"fontSize":12,"openLinksInNewTab":false,"markdown":"#  Retweets Network
## Use of this dashboard
This section presents a network composed of interconnected nodes. The main nodes represent users who have been retweeted—the larger the node, the greater the number of retweets accumulated. Secondary nodes correspond to users who perform the retweets, and the edges connecting them increase in thickness according to the number of retweets linking secondary to primary nodes.
Filters can be applied by emotion, sentiment, or user to facilitate targeted exploration of the network."}}

attributes.description: Tutorial for the use of dashboards and tweets analysis.
attributes.title: Tutorial for Dashboards
attributes.visState:
{"title":"Tutorial for Dashboards","type":"markdown","aggs":[],"params":{"fontSize":12,"markdown":"# TUTORIAL
Here you will find several use cases illustrating how to work with these dashboards to extract meaningful insights and identify potential misinformation patterns. Experiment with these examples as an idea to get started, but feel free to play around and find the configurations that best suit you for your analyses.

1.   **Let’s explore what lies behind the use of the hashtag #CLIMATECRISIS** (all hashtags have been capitalized to standardize casing).
To do this, open the [Hashtags](/app/dashboards#/view/a447aed0-a9a3-11f0-86b9-7f07a1b75750) dashboard. Then apply a filter, either by clicking directly on the hashtag you want to analyze or by creating a new filter from scratch in the top panel and assigning it to the “hashtags” field.
Then, you can examine all resulting tweets containing that hashtag (possibly alongside others) across the different visualizations.
We will focus on the “Tweets per Emotion” chart, which plots tweets over time along with the emotions assigned by the model. In this case, we can observe a predominance of disgust and fear in certain periods, as well as 'joy' in others.

2.    **Now, let's study the retweet network**. 
In the [Retweets Graph](/app/dashboards#/view/6f5dc862-d9df-49cd-9332-90b3dd17a33e) dashboard, we find a network composed of _main nodes_ (retweeted users) and _secondary nodes_ (retweeters), connected by edges whose thickness reflects the number of retweets.
Our goal here is to identify the most retweeted users associated with certain emotions. We apply a filter for fear by clicking on the _'Emotions and Sentiment'_ pie chart, as well as the '-1' _(Negative)_ sentiment.
This allows us to visualize which users have been retweeted in tweets with these characteristics, who retweeted them, and which other users those retweeters have also amplified.

3.   *Finally, we analyze the objectives and narratives*.
Tweets have been processed to identify the strategic intent behind their narratives. We explore this within the [Objectives and Stance](/app/dashboards#/view/c282d5d0-b972-11f0-b852-49ba90b8a171) dashboard.
Let’s begin by examining what happens when we filter by the objective “WEAKEN THE OPPONENT’S IMAGE, PRESENCE, IDENTITY, IDEOLOGY, OR VALUES.”
We would expect that tweets expressing this intention to display predominantly negative emotions—such as disgust or anger. This can be explored by looking at the “Tweets per Date and Emotion” visualization, where the distribution of labeled emotions over time is shown.
Additional Emotion or Sentiment filters can be applied by clicking on the “Emotions and Sentiments” chart on the right side of the dashboard.
Finally, the resulting tweets can be downloaded from the bottom table by clicking the “Download CSV” button.

Now I encourage you to follow these steps to learn how the dashboards work and start playing around with the interactive visualizations, and get your own results and conclusions.

## Acknowledgements
This work was supported by the [HAMiSoN project](https://nlp.uned.es/hamison-project/) grant CHIST-ERA-21-OSNEM-002, AEI PCI2022-135026-2 (MCIN/AEI/10.13039/501100011033 and EU “NextGenerationEU”/PRTR)

","openLinksInNewTab":false}}

Explanation for Tweets per emotion dahsboard
attributes.visState:
{"title":"Explanation for Tweets per emotion dahsboard","type":"markdown","aggs":[],"params":{"fontSize":12,"openLinksInNewTab":false,"markdown":"# Tweets per Emotion
## Use of this Dashboard
This dashboard permits the exploration of tweets categorized by their labeled emotion or sentiment. In the “Tweets per Date” graph, users can select specific date ranges (particularly those corresponding to peaks in certain emotions).
Filters can be applied by clicking on the legend within the visualization; these selections will automatically update all visualizations across the dashboard.
(Remember that filters may also be pinned across multiple dashboards to support extended analysis).

The table below displays the tweets remaining after filters have been applied, allowing for further filtering or detailed examination.
To download this data in CSV format, click the small download button located beneath the table title."}}

attributes.description: Exploration of tweets by their labeled emotion or sentiment selecting specific date ranges.

attributes.visState: {"title":"Explanation for hashtags Dashboard","type":"markdown","aggs":[],"params":{"fontSize":16,"openLinksInNewTab":false,"markdown":"#  Hashtags\n## Use of this dashboard\nA tag cloud displaying the main hashtags used in the dataset is shown below. Users can filter tweets by clicking on specific hashtags to view the associated posts. Conversely, it is also possible to filter by emotion or sentiment to examine which hashtags are most frequently linked to those emotional responses within the tweets."}}

attributes.description: Intended for hashtag filtering and correlation with emotions in tweet analysis.
attributes.title: Hashtags Dashboard
Explanation for Objectives Dashboard
attributes.visState:
{"title":"Explanation for Objectives Dashboard","type":"markdown","aggs":[],"params":{"fontSize":12,"openLinksInNewTab":false,"markdown":"# Objectives and Stance
## How to use
This dashboard presents the narratives (objectives) extracted by a Large Language Model (LLM) for each tweet, along with the corresponding emotions and sentiment analysis.
Users can filter tweets by emotion or objective and explore potential correlations between the displayed graphs.
The table below contains the resulting tweets, allowing users to view detailed information (e.g., text, user, date) and export the data in CSV format."}}

attributes.description: This dashboard presents the narratives (objectives) extracted by a Large Language Model (LLM) for each tweet, along with the corresponding emotions and sentiment analysis. Users can filter tweets by emotion or objective and explore potential correlations between the displayed graphs. The table below contains the resulting tweets, allowing users to view detailed information (e.g., text, user, date) and export the data in CSV format.
